questions: What is the Adult Day Program in Burlingame?
Tell me about the Adult Day Program, Burlingame.
answer: Adult Day Program, Burlingame provides adults with developmental disabilities (ages 18 and older) with community-based day services that build skills and experiential knowledge so they can make informed decisions and participate in employment, volunteering, and social or recreational activities. It serves adults in San Mateo County who are not currently served by the school system and who do not require staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent behavioral or safety issues. The program is based at 899 Stanton Rd, Burlingame, CA 94010 and also meets at various locations in the local community. Services are offered five days per week, Monday through Friday, from 9:00 AM to 3:00 PM, with part-time Monday/Wednesday/Friday and Tuesday/Thursday options. To get started, contact your Regional Center Service Coordinator and ask them to email a referral packet to intake@abilitypath.org; required documents typically include a Facesheet, CDER, Current IPP, Medical Report, Psychological Report, and Social Report.

Tell me about the Adult Day Program, Daly City.

questions: What is the Community Access Adult Day Program?
Tell me about Community Access Adult Day Program.
answer: The Community Access Adult Day Program is a community-based day program for adults with developmental disabilities that focuses on providing experiential knowledge and skills so participants can make informed decisions and engage in their preferred types and levels of community involvement, including employment, volunteering, and social or recreational activities. It serves adults ages 18 and older in San Mateo County who have a developmental disability, are not currently served by the school system, and do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Services take place at various locations in the community rather than one fixed site. The program typically operates five days per week, Monday through Friday, from 9:00 AM to 3:00 PM, with part-time Monday/Wednesday/Friday and Tuesday/Thursday options. To get started, contact your Regional Center Service Coordinator and ask them to email a referral packet to intake@abilitypath.org; required documents typically include a Facesheet, CDER, Current IPP, Medical Report, Psychological Report, and Social Report.

questions: What is the Adult Day Program in San Jose?
Tell me about the Adult Day Program, San Jose.
answer: Adult Day Program, San Jose is a community-based day program that supports adults with developmental disabilities (ages 18 and older) in building skills and experiential knowledge so they can make informed decisions and participate in employment, volunteering, and social or recreational activities. The program is based out of 2248 N. First Street, San Jose, CA 95131, and activities take place at various locations in the local community. Tell me about the Adult Day Program, Palo Alto.
answer: Adult Day Program, Palo Alto is a community-based day program for adults with developmental disabilities (ages 18 and older) that helps participants gain experiential knowledge and skills to make informed choices and engage in employment, volunteering, and social or recreational activities. questions: What is the Youth Social Recreation program?
Tell me about Youth Social Recreation.
answer: Youth Social Recreation offers inclusive programming for youth ages 12 to 17 with developmental disabilities, focusing on building meaningful connections, friendships, and exploring abilities and interests through social and recreational activities. It serves youth in San Mateo County and Santa Clara County who have a developmental disability and do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Programs take place at various locations in the community or at an AbilityPath site. Days and times vary across weekends, weeknights, summers, and school breaks; upcoming programs are posted at https://abilitypath.org/services/adult-services/social-recreation-programs/. To begin the intake process, families can email socialrec@abilitypath.org.

questions: What is the Adult Social Recreation program?
Tell me about Adult Social Recreation.
answer: Adult Social Recreation offers inclusive programming for adults ages 18 to 30 with developmental disabilities, focusing on building meaningful connections, friendships, and exploring abilities and interests through social and recreational experiences. It serves adults in San Mateo County and Santa Clara County who have a developmental disability and do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Activities take place at various locations in the community or at an AbilityPath site, with days and times varying across weekends, weeknights, summers, and school breaks. To get started, individuals or families can email socialrec@abilitypath.org to begin the intake process.

questions: What is Independent Living Skills, North?
Tell me about the Independent Living Skills program in the North region.
answer: Independent Living Skills, North (ILS North) provides one-on-one coaching at home or in the community to help adults with developmental disabilities learn everyday skills such as cooking, cleaning, budgeting, travel, safety, and socializing, with the goal of building confidence and living more independently. It serves adults ages 18 and older who have a developmental disability, live in the area from San Francisco to Palo Alto, and do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Services are delivered at the individual's residence or in the community, with scheduling that is flexible and arranged mutually between the individual and the assigned staff member. To begin the intake process, individuals should contact their Regional Center Service Coordinator and request that they email a referral packet to intake@abilitypath.org; required documents typically include a Facesheet, CDER, Current IPP, Medical Report, Psychological Report, and Social Report.

questions: What is Independent Living Skills, South?
Tell me about the Independent Living Skills program in the South region.
answer: Independent Living Skills, South (ILS South) offers one-on-one coaching at home or in the community to help adults with developmental disabilities learn everyday skills like cooking, cleaning, budgeting, travel, safety, and socializing, supporting greater independence. It serves adults ages 18 and older who have a developmental disability, live in areas between Palo Alto and Santa Cruz, and do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Services are provided at the individual's residence or in the community, with scheduling that is flexible and agreed upon between the participant and the assigned staff member. To get started, individuals should contact their Regional Center Service Coordinator and ask them to email a referral packet to intake@abilitypath.org; required documents usually include a Facesheet, CDER, and Current IPP.

questions: What is Tailored Day Services in San Mateo County?
Tell me about Tailored Day Services, San Mateo County.
answer: Tailored Day Services, San Mateo County is a one-on-one service where participants work directly with an instructor to build skills for a more independent and inclusive life. Services are pre-employment focused and may include job exploration, social and recreational activities, college support, daily living skills, and personal interest pursuits. It serves adults ages 18 and older with developmental disabilities in San Mateo County who are not served by the school system and who do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Services take place at various locations in the community or at an AbilityPath site, with scheduling that is flexible and arranged mutually between the individual and the assigned staff member. To begin the intake process, participants should contact their Regional Center Service Coordinator and request that they email a referral packet to intake@abilitypath.org; required documents typically include a Facesheet, CDER, Current IPP, Medical Report, Psychological Report, and Social Report.

questions: What are Employment Services in San Mateo County?
Tell me about Employment Services, San Mateo County.
answer: Employment Services, San Mateo County supports adults ages 18 and older with developmental disabilities in building foundational workplace readiness and progressing along their employment journey. Services may include customized employment tracks such as paid internships, group employment, or job placement, along with resume and cover letter development, interview preparation and support, and dedicated job coaching to maximize success. It serves adults in San Mateo County who have a developmental disability and do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Services are provided at various locations in the community or at an AbilityPath site, with scheduling that is flexible and arranged between the individual and staff. To get started, individuals typically apply through the Department of Rehabilitation (DOR) by completing a DOR Application Form and submitting it to their local DOR office. Once the application is processed, DOR sends AbilityPath a referral packet, and AbilityPath then contacts the individual directly to continue the intake process.

questions: What are Employment Services in Santa Clara County?
Tell me about Employment Services, Santa Clara County.
answer: Employment Services, Santa Clara County supports adults ages 18 and older in developing workplace readiness and advancing toward community-based employment through customized employment options such as paid internships, group employment, or job placement. Services are designed to maximize success and may include resume and cover letter support, interview preparation and coaching, and ongoing job coaching. It serves adults in Santa Clara County who have an intellectual or developmental disability or, in some cases, a stroke or traumatic brain injury, and who do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Services are delivered at various locations in the community, with flexible scheduling arranged between the participant and staff. To begin the intake process, individuals generally work through the Department of Rehabilitation (DOR): they complete a DOR Application Form, submit it to their local DOR office, and once the application is processed, DOR sends a referral packet to AbilityPath, which then contacts the individual directly to continue the intake process.

questions: What is the Immersion Work Readiness Program?
Tell me about the Immersion Work Readiness Program.
answer: The Immersion Work Readiness Program prepares individuals with a range of disabilities for meaningful, community-based employment. It serves adults 18 and older who are not being served by the school system and who have disabilities including, but not limited to, physical, intellectual, developmental, mental health conditions, stroke, and traumatic brain injury, with eligibility considered on a case-by-case basis. Through structured, small-group modules and individualized service planning, the program helps participants build work readiness skills and the supports needed to succeed in inclusive workplace settings. The program is offered in Santa Clara County at 2248 N. First Street, San Jose, CA 95131. It typically operates five days per week, Monday through Friday, from 9:00 AM to 2:00 PM. Because this is a new program, the intake process depends on how the chatbot and interest collection are set up: if the chatbot records participantsâ€™ interest and has their contact information, AbilityPath will reach out directly; if not, individuals should be referred to fill out the AbilityPath Interest Form. The process is expected to change in the future once the program has been approved by the Department of Rehabilitation.

questions: What is the Creative Arts Program?
Tell me about the upcoming Creative Arts Program.
answer: The Creative Arts Program is an upcoming program that empowers adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities to express themselves creatively, develop artistic and vocational skills, and build community connections through the arts in inclusive community and studio environments. It serves adults ages 18 and older in Santa Clara County who have a developmental disability, are not served by the school system, and do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. The program is planned to be offered at 525 East Charleston Road, Palo Alto, CA 94306. Days and times are still to be determined. Because this is a new program, how someone gets started depends on the chatbot process: if the chatbot captures that they are interested and has their contact information, AbilityPath will contact them directly; otherwise, they should be referred to complete the AbilityPath Interest Form. The intake process is expected to evolve once the program has been approved by San Andreas Regional Center.

questions: What is the REACH program for stroke and traumatic brain injury?
Tell me about REACH (Stroke and Traumatic Brain Injury Services).
answer: REACH (Stroke and Traumatic Brain Injury Services) offers therapeutic services and programming for people who have experienced a stroke or traumatic brain injury, bringing together services previously provided by two organizations. Participants receive support from licensed physical, speech, and occupational therapists with extensive learning and hands-on service expertise. It serves individuals in San Mateo County or Santa Clara County who have had a stroke or traumatic brain injury and who do not require AbilityPath staff support for restroom use, eating, mobility, medical needs, taking medication, or frequent disruptive or dangerous behaviors or eloping. Services are provided at Cubberley Community Center, 4000 Middlefield Road, Building P, Palo Alto, CA 94303. Class schedules and one-on-one session times vary; individuals should contact braininjuryservices@abilitypath.org for current offerings. To begin the intake process, people are asked to email braininjuryservices@abilitypath.org.
